content.webTitle: Australian man who fled Syria says he never joined 'vicious and cruel' Isis

fields.headline: Australian man who fled Syria says he never joined 'vicious and cruel' Isis
fields.bodyText: A Melbourne man accused of links to Islamic State who is seeking to return to Australia claims he never joined the militia group, was taken to its territory inadvertently, and only went to Syria “to use my skills as a nurse and medic to help the Syrian people”. Adam Brookman, a married father of five in his late 30s, is the real name of “Abu Ibrahim”, one of at least three Australians trying to negotiate their return home to Australia from the four-year Syrian conflict. Speaking in Turkey, Brookman told the Guardian he had been taken to Isis-held territory in Syria after being injured in an air strike and had been banned from leaving. “It was not permitted for foreigners to leave their areas to what [Isis] called apostate areas,” he said. “And to go to Turkey is also forbidden, they have an edict that basically forbids anyone from leaving their area.” The Australian-born Muslim, whose interest in Islam was kindled during a gap year visit to Morocco, said he had never taken up arms with or joined Isis, and had only worked in clinics and hospitals in the war-torn country. He now wished to return to his wife and children in Melbourne, he said. Brookman told the Guardian he had entered Syria early in 2014 with the aid of an Australian humanitarian worker based in Turkey because he wanted to use his nursing skills to assist with the humanitarian crisis among the Syrian people. He eventually found his way to Aleppo, “where I worked on ambulances, transporting civilians who were injured due to bombing and fire from jets, which would happen every night”, he said. Fighting in Aleppo has been particularly fierce over the course of Syria’s four-year civil war and the city is now divided between troops loyal to President Bashar al-Assad, Free Syrian army forces and Islamist groups. All have been accused of indiscriminate killing of civilians. Brookman said fighting in the city became so bad by June 2014 “that I was forced to go further west towards a place called Atme”. “There we had less to do, but used to work with the refugees camps there delivering clothing, and also water transported from Turkey.” He said he had linked up with other health workers, most of whom were Syrian but some were Europeans. “They were always Muslims,” he said. “It’s not safe for people who aren’t Muslims. “At the time we were working in temporary clinics and living out of garages. We had to keep moving, if you stay in one place too long there’s a risk of being targeted by the government, they have a habit of targeting hospitals, clinics and places of worship. About the time Islamic State declared it had formed a caliphate on 30 June last year, Brookman’s clinic in Atme was bombed. “One of our colleagues was killed and myself and a couple of others were injured,” he said. He claims to have sustained injuries to his shoulder and right foot and was struck in the head. He told the Guardian he had been taken by ambulance to al-Bab, an area controlled by Isis with a large hospital. “It was at night, we were taken at night by ambulance to a hospital,” he said. “I was unconscious at the time, but from what I was told we were taken to an area that was under Isis control.” After a few days he was moved to a recovery house, where he said he began to understand it was assumed he would join the militant group. “They quite fully expected me to join with the group, being a Muslim and being a foreigner … The vast majority [of foreigners] who are there are fighters,” he said. “[Isis] don’t put a gun to your head … and also the fact that I was injured meant they weren’t pushing the fact, but their assumption was that when I recovered I would join them in some capacity,” he said. Brookman maintains that after his recovery he never joined the group: “I didn’t do the training at all, I managed to avoid doing things like that by getting back into medical work. So they kind of left me alone. There are lots of refugees there and the city of al-Bab is subject to a lot of aerial bombardment in surrounding areas.” He claimed he had felt under constant suspicion by Isis militants. “I didn’t agree with some of their beliefs about who is and isn’t Muslim, and that’s quite a dangerous thought process to have,” he said. “No one who’s smart would voice such disagreements, because people like that are thrown in jail and subjected to vigorous questioning … they’ll get quite physical. “There’s also the fear of infiltration and spies, so anyone who wants to leave is basically assumed to be a spy, because to them, why would anyone want to leave?” Witnessing atrocities under the group’s rule convinced him “they are bad, there’s no doubt about it”, he said. “[Isis is] quite vicious and cruel and they torture people, and there’s a no-apologetic execution to what they do. If you’re with them they’re friendly but if you’re against them it’s fire and brimstone.” He claims to have witnessed the aftermath of the crucifixion of an alleged Assad regime spy and the stoning of a couple accused of adultery. He said these punishments were in keeping with sharia law, “which is something all Muslims want to have, but done correctly, not gangster-style”. He said between August and December he resolved that “as soon as I could get out of here, I would get out”. A Syrian he trusted put him in touch with a human trafficker working out of Turkey, he said, and in late December he made a break for the Turkish border. “I went to stay at a friend’s house and, after two days, a taxi driver came. With a bit of negotiation, because they’re understandably scared of being caught, he took me to a border village.” Brookman and the driver dodged Isis patrols and drove to a farm straddling the border between Turkey and Syria, he claimed. “After a 2km run across farmland and then over a barbed wire fence, I found myself in Turkey.” He said his passport had been stolen earlier in 2014 and, in Turkey, he asked the Australian embassy for a replacement. “Initially they said no problem … A few days later I got a call saying my passport’s been cancelled, I’ve been suspected of terrorism and this and that.” Through his lawyer, Rob Stary, he had commenced negotiations with the Australian federal police to return home, he said. “We understand that, of course, I’d have to be investigated, just by the very nature of where I’ve been, but hoping that I wouldn’t be arrested and thrown in jail before such an investigation could take place.” He said the talks were ongoing but police had so far been adamant he would be arrested upon arriving in Australia. “I never entered in any fighting, I never participated in any attacks of any sort,” he said. “The role that I did was in my capacity as a nurse and medic and in dispensing clothing, water.” Brookman admits he treated Isis fighters in the course of his work. “We work in a clinic and you help who comes in. I’m not there to check IDs and see who I’m helping and not helping. “If someone comes in injured you do what you do and then move on to the next patient.” He said while Australia did not implement sharia law, “it’s also not a war-torn country and it’s not divided by different sects and groups. I was born in Australia and grew up in Australia and it’s my home”. “It’s not perfect, but what country is?” he said. He would “look into” working with young people to dissuade them from joining Isis upon his return, Brookman said. “There would be benefit in opening the eyes of some of the youth that are clouded by the glitz and glamour of jihad,” he said. “I’d tell them the reality, that it’s not what you’re thinking, this utopia that people are making it out to be. They think that they’re doing jihad against the Syrian regime but they could be fighting against other Muslims in certain areas. “There’s a lot of restrictions, you can’t leave and there’s that ever-present suspicion of everyone so you watch what you say, there’s no freedom to question certain things. “If people want to help Syria, you go through proper channels, of charity groups that are helping the Syrians.” The prime minister, Tony Abbott, said on Tuesday there would be no exceptions made for Australians seeking to return who were suspected of having joined Isis. “A crime is a crime is a crime,” he said. “If you go abroad to break Australian law, if you go abroad to kill innocent people in the name of misguided fundamentalism and extremism, if you go abroad to become an Islamist killer, well, we are hardly going to welcome you back into this country.”
